availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: ["Whitman, Walt, poet, was born..."], autobiographical statement, holograph, corrected
bibl.orgName: Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

The prose drafted on the back of these and several other related manuscript leaves includes ideas and phrases that resemble those used in "Unnamed Lands," a poem published first in the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass.

body.p: Walt Whitman ‸ ‸ Walt, poet, was born May 31, 1819, on his fathers at his parents' farm house, West Hills, western Suffolk county, Long Island, New York State; of English stockonfrom the father's side , and onfrom that of the mother (Louisa Van Velsor) of Holland Dutch. The family moved to Brooklyn early; and in that place, and in New York City, W. W's boyhood and early manhood passed. He went to the public schools, and in due time learned the printer's trade, and worked at it. He p n also lived in the country, ‸ Long Island taught school, labored at farm⹀toil and house⹀building and published a weekly newspaper. New York and Brooklyn however, were his principal headquarters till nearly 30 years of age, when he started traveling, first to Louisiana, forpassing a year there, and then to leisurely visits and occupation, in nearly all the Southern and Western States, one after the other. Then returning to Brooklyn, he put in shape and issued (1855) the first portion of Leaves of Grass, which has been fashioned and increased until now (1888) is is considered finished, by the author's last pieces, Sands at Seventy, as annex to the previous ones.

During 1862 to 1865 ‸ inclusive W W was was arduously occupied in the area of the Civil War in Maryland and Virginia and in ‸ and around Washington City absorbed with the wounded and sick of the armies both northern and southern; giving ‸ fully three years with to those special ministerings. He had always been of always possessed the best health and strength, but soon about the close of the contest, he was prostrated ‸ by a severe stroke of paralysis. Though he surmount-
ed surmounted
it, a broken physique remainedresulted and some six attacks have at times resultedfollowed from it since. His literary works are comprehended under three titles, his the Leaves of Grass, hishis main work and form of poetic expression, and his main work, passing through five stages or increments, beginning in 1855 and completed in 1888; his prose book, Specimen Days and Coll Collect, issued 1883, forming biographical notes, memoranda of personal memoranda during the Civil War, with various essays including Democratic Vistas; and lastly a smaller book November Boughs, of poems and prose. He has never recovered from the physical paralysis of the war period and agitation of 1855 to 1860 to 1865, ‸ but, ‸ his mental powers remaining unaffected, he has steadily worked at his literary plans and induring 1888, atin his 70th year, finished histhe booklet off November Boughs, his last work.
